Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 04:58PM mgdsmc wrote: azrescue I'm so sorry you are dealing with this and I understand your fear. We have all been there. Just remember that everyone is different. Whatever you decide to do its your decision. I was braids 4 and my biopsy came back postive, most arent. Please stay off of google will only scare yourself. The question you have to ask yourself is can you live with the decision of waiting 3 months if it comes back positive? Most breast cancer dosent grow to rapid so if its there would probably be the same results if you wait. No one wants a biopsy if we don't have to but don't let fear of pain be a factor. Mine didn't hurt at all. From what you said you will probably have one anyway so why wait? Get it over with so you can continue on with your life instead of constant worrying. Good results will lift your spirit and if its BC than you will face and beat it like the rest of us. Loosing a parent to cancer hurts no matter how old you are. I'm sure you don't want your family to lose you like you lost your dad. My profession advice is to have the biopsy. No one can tell if its cancer or not by looking and feeling. It's only diagnosed after biopsy so even though the doctor said it looked like cancer dosent mean it is. The doctor that took my tissue didn't think I had BC but I did. Remember it's your body and decision, not an easy one to make. I'm sure you will make the best choice for you. I'm keeping my fingers crossed for a negative result if you have it done. Michelle

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 04:17PM mgdsmc wrote: I just had fat grafting last week 8/16 and post op last Friday. I think this is the procedure the PS is recommending for your mom. I have no incisions, came home same day and full recovery before my post op appt. I wasn't happy with my results when I removed my dressings. My fat was removed from my lower back and under arms, no scars. At my post op I learned that I will need 5 more surgeries, not all done at once like I thought. I think he told me that long time ago. It's like the BRAVA procedure women are having without the cones, think that's what they're called. It making my breast larger more round and after more of a real feel. I don't have implants did tram flap, love it! Last radiation was 4/2/13. Will have surgery every 6-8 weeks until they are the way I want. Next surgery 10/18/13. Was the easiest surgery I ever had. Was walking my dogs a mile the same day. No pain just a little sore. I'm not a fan of the number of surgeries, can get implant at anytime but don't want one. I had nipple/skin sparing double MX last October 28, 2012. Didn't have the tightness like your mom. Hope this helps

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 01:01PM mgdsmc wrote: Hello Ladies! I'm not actually a newbie had my last chemo 10/2/12 and last radiation 4/2/13. Was diagnosed 2/15/12. Oh I remember how I felt after my first surgery. Went in thinking I was stage zero or one coming out stage 3a with 6/10 nodes positive! My heart broke at the thought of my kids growing up without me. Sad depressed scared looked out the window wondering how many more sun rises or sunsets I would see. So much love and support from family and friends but as you know unless you have experienced it can't understand. So today I can honestly say it gets better with time. I know it doesn't seem like it but once you are done with treatment you think less about dying and just live normally again. No you will never be the person you were before BC you will be stronger having lived through treatment. The fear is always there but one day you will wake up and BC won't be on your mind. This is what I learned. The way we look at things can affect our moods and thought of out come. Yes the more node the worse the prognosis but as many have said just statics. Think of it this way, lymph nodes are there as protectors, to catch the cancer before it goes to an organ so they did their job. Some people have 40 lymph nodes so only having 3, 10, 20 ect still give you many nodes that are cancer free. Chemo, surgery, radiation hormonal therapy all increase the chances that our bodies are cancer free. No one can guarantee that we won't get it again nor can they say we will as with all diseases. You will be on meds for depression, sleep, anxiety ect for a long time if needed and that's ok. I wasn't on any meds except for high cholesterol before than I was on what seem to be 20 or more for all kinds of issues now just on tamoxifen and Effexor for hot flashes. As for as not being cured my MO told me this "We cure stage 3 all the time" as far as he's concerned I'm cured until something tells him it's back. He only uses NED for stage 4 patients. No scans unless symptoms just routine bloodwork. It like glass half empty half full. Living life being cured is easier than walking around NED. So it's your outlook on life. I know at this moment that's very dark and scary but there is light at the end of the tunnel and life after treatment. Just be patient with yourself. Uncertainty, the unknown about treatments working or if they got it all, sadness, dispear ect is normal. Some people take months others years but eventually it will be ok. I never thought the day of treatment would end but it did and so will yours! Sorry for the short novel but stage 3 is scary and I want to offer hope to those who are where I wasðŸ˜Š

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2013 10:49PM mgdsmc wrote: ballet12 I'm so sorry to hear about your issues. I'm sure it's not helping with your stress level. You are entitled to feel whatever you feel no need to apologize. You have lots of valid questions that need to be answered by your surgeon not us. It appears that the language they used were medical and unless you work in the field it's confusing. You have to understand the procedure before you sign the consent. The surgeon is the one who should explain not the nurse. Second get a copy of your report. That way you can look up the terms and the reason for there concern. Plus you will see how much tissue was removed and what was said about each one. Third they will do everything for you. No need for you to worry about that. You should get preop instructions in advance and the Anesthesiologist should call you the night before. Once you do these things you should be more comfortable with your decision. Good luck! Michelle

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2012 08:21PM mgdsmc wrote: Taking pain meds alone will constipated. Not sure why they don't address that during our hospital stay. I brought my own with me and took 4 a day and no Diarrah or loose stool. The key to keeping pain level down is to take them when you have very little pain like 3 or 4 level. The goal is to not feel pain or let it get out of control. I know everyone is afraid of addiction but that only happens when you take it when you don't need it. My pain is about 3-4 but I take one Percocet every 4-6 hours. Itching is another story. It's a sign of healing but so irritating I take beneadryl for that every 4-6 hours depend on how much I'm itching. I see both my BS and PS on Friday. Everything is looking good still have my ace wrap on for compression comfort but can see my 2 dressing over where my breast use to be. I think my drains will stay until next week since I'm still having lots of output. Well I'm going to lay back down. I get so tired no matter what I do. I almost fell today trying to open my window. My daughters were so upset with me. I broke a candle holder breaking my fall. They said I will be on timeout if I try it again :)

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 09:58PM mgdsmc wrote: Shirley It's weird that we had the same chemo but different types of nausea meds. My steroids were given IV while on AC. Emend should be taken for 3 days the morning before and 2 mornings after is that what you are doing? Not sure of what other medical issues you have but the correct dose for zofran should be 8mg not 4mg. It was proven in a study that 4mg doesn't help nausea related to chemo. Promethazine is better than zofran and sometimes helps with sleep. Ask why they didn't give you 8 mg of zofran to take. I know you aren't really sleeping because of the steroids you are taking every 8 hours. Get a Rx for something it won't give you 8 hours of sleep but you will get a few hours. No one wants to eat or drink when nauseated no matter how much you are encouraged. They need to change your nausea meds. You can take 2 of the 4mg zofran and you will feel better until you ask why. As an RN I get upset with things like this. I'm not sure the reason they aren't giving you the 3 pills of Emand nor the correct doses to prevent this. Your body needs nutrients and this is ridiculous!

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 06:11AM mgdsmc wrote: Had my pre op MRI, CXR and EKG yesterday. Also had pre-op with PS. Went over the procedure again signed consent and got pre op instructions. They told me the same thing when I had my reduction but it did come back in about 6-9 months. Plus women on the boards are saying there sensation is returning too. I will take my chances. I will have to have fat grafting and liposuction to fill the extra space in the pocket later. I forgot to ask if it will be before or after radiation. He said my radiation should be easier since no implant. More importantly he said if I'm not happy with my breast I can always get implants later without needing TE and all covered by insurance. So BC causes me to lose my D cup breast replace with A- B cup, gives me a flatter tummy, liposuction and fat removal from places where I have too much. Always have to look at the bright side. That's a very small price to pay for a longer life. Now just waiting for MRI results to add to the bright side. Hope everyone is doing good.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 12:56PM mgdsmc wrote: NYCMOM3- When I made the decision to have BMX and saw the PS who told me "they're only breast' was my first major breakdown. My daughter told me how can you next cry? You are loosing a part of you. It normal to mourn them. She was right. We all have new bodies we have to get use to just takes lots if time. I don't think any of us thought about loosing whole or part of our breast before this but we made the choice to live, that was the easy part. The steps to fight is the hard part but when has a fight ever been easy? When our wounds are healed and the fight is won we will think it was worth every tear we cried. We are cancer free! CindyLooWho- Congradulations on not needing to see MO again. I'm sure that was a big relief. Yes I went to the mall and shopped for 2 hours. It was my first outing since surgery. I brought me a really cute mini skirt and blouse ( without trying them on) can you imagine that site if i did? i have 4 drains and abdominal binder wouldn't know where to start. I took a Percocet before and walked slower than normal. I get so upset that doctors don't really give us a chance to sit and think about what we want to do. It's rush rush rush. I went back and forth with what surgery I wanted and could live with. Not that implants are bad and sometimes the only choice but its so emotional. Not one doctor told me all my options I learned about them on my own. I was with another group when diagnosed. The BS was good but both PS just flat out said that flaps were too much work. I remember thinking for who you or me? Having to visit every 2 weeks to get fills for 6 months, waiting for tattoos and whatever else seems harder on me. That's when I changed my medical group. Lots of people don't know you can do that. I still part of the same network but diffentent better group. I had my first appt on a Wednesday and present me to the tumor board in Friday. They listened to me about what I wanted for reconstruction and why. I hate when people say don't make your decision out if fear, are you kidding me? How can I not. I'm thankful I had 5 months to make a final decision. We all picked what was right for us and everyone will have an emotion response to seeing our breast area afterwards. I'm disfigured with deflated breast inside a pocket not a pretty site at all. I didn't cry because I got what I asked for that's the most important thing to remember. We are scared, holes from drain or drains and missing part of our womanhood but grow stronger each day. Next year this time we will be use to our new bodies and graftful that its over.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 10:10PM mgdsmc wrote: Paula I'm sorry you are having a little problem with the chemo. Yes lots of people do experience that. As I said before eating is the key. I know you aren't hungry and no energy but you need calories. They are very important in building your new cells. The first couple of days I was tired but better day 4 was ok. Some people experience fevers it's winter and once again food plays a role. WBC will drop everyone does its the bidies reaction to chemo but it depends how low it goes that's important. Your WBCs will increase but chemo will bring it back down. If you get chilly again take your temp and keep Tylenol on hand, helps with headache.Ensure high protein is great when you aren't hungry. I drank one every 2-3 hours no matter what. Your depression.will stay for awhile part of the chemo. It will pass in time especially once you start taxol so much better.AC is hard on some people pills help but food is better. Btw cold skin doesn't mean you don't have a fever. Ask you MO what he considers a fever it varies by doctors some say anything over 100 other it's 101.5 degrees. Michelle

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 01:38PM mgdsmc wrote: Hi Karen Glad you found our group. I'm sorry you are having a hard time understanding what going on with your treatment but we will try to help you. First the meeting your doctor is talking about is probably a tumor board. They present cases to multiple doctors BS, MO RO and PS and discuss the best treatment for you. With mine I had to be there as I was presented. It's great because its like having second third fourth ect opinions. Second it sounds as if your margins weren't clear when they removed the tumor which is usually the reason for another surgery with lumpectomies. Third as far as a little amount of cancer in your nodes it is gray because depending on how much some would say it was negative. So it's up to your team to decide if you need chemo or radiation maybe both depending on your menopausal status. The best advice I can offer is to get a copy of your pathology report. It will be confusing to you at first but this site will help you with the terms. Some of us have been where you are and some exactly where you are. We are hear to help each other get through this together. You aren't alone. Ask us as many questions as you want and we will do our best to answer. :)

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 08:47PM mgdsmc wrote: Hello Ladies Well I'm here to tell you the sleepless nights have to do with the chemo and anxiety. I felt like you guys hate taking so many meds and wanted to just sleep like a normal person, never happened. I was on ambiem 10mg, melatonin 10mg and now restoril ever now and than mostly due to surgery pain. Once I was done with chemo it was much easier to sleep and not addicted to any of them. Remember addiction usually happens when meds are taken when not needed. So swallow your pride take the meds a d get some sleep. You probably won't sleep all night but will get a few hours in. I had 3 of my 4 drains removed today, so happy. I slept in my bed for the first time at a 45 degree angle, abdomen still really tight but I'm feeling much better. You guys have to keep telling yourself this is only temporary because it is. Take the meds you have because once you are done they will take them away. They are there to help your body deal with the changes. Once your done and your body returns to almost as it was before you will forget that you ever needed them :)

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 02:42PM mgdsmc wrote: Hello ladies! Welcome to all the new members of our club that none of us wanted to join. maryah930- I think we all had a pity party once or twice and normal. I'm probably one of the few here who has dealt with this for 8 months. I can tell everyone it really does get easier with time and knowledge. BC still enter my mind daily (can't help it since I'm still bald) but the sadness isn't present like it use to be. No more looking out the window and wondering how many more sunsets and sun rises I will see, how will my kids survive without me ect. Now I actually say things like next year, joke all the time as usual, eating normal ect. One thing I do is spend more time with my girls. They have been sleeping with me since i started chemo in last May. Qandyland- I know the shock of hearing node involvement, not easy. No one told me the effects of the nodes being removed before surgery. I had 10 nodes removed and sensation like being at the dentist numb but can feel when touched. Very important that you guys work on your range of motion in the arm that nodes were removed if not will lose full range of motion so the sooner the better. Yes I will hurt a lot but not forever. Stand next to the wall and place your fingers on it, start crawling up the wall like a spider at least 10 times a day. You won't get far in the beginning but will get better. Another one is to have someone lift your arm slowly for you because you will feel resistance,pulling and pain. It took about 2-3 weeks before my range was normal. I don't know how people go back to work in such a short time. I know I'm a wimp I haven't worked since March 29 the day if my first surgery!

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 08:38PM mgdsmc wrote: Hello Ladies Sorry it took so long to give a update but as you know just so tired. Friday surgery went well. I was able to get in a chair but wasn't easy. After surgery I couldn't pee even with the Foley catheter in place and my heart rate stayed over 100 but felt fine just sleepy. They did stat labs on me around 1am and the doctor on call can to see me, labs were normal but he ordered them in 6 hours. By the morning my heart rate was in the 120's-130's with increased blood pressure, hgb was 8.2 normal is over 9 so no transfusions. My PS came to see me asked how I was doing I said ok. Than the charge nurse, intensive care charge nurse and 2 floor nurses came rushing in. My heart rate was over 170 blood pressure was dropping and very little output. My PS was shocked felt my abdomen and say we need to get you to surgery stat! The nurses had been checking on me and I know it takes awhile for the bleed to show up. They had just did my bloodwork and my hgb 6.8 critical is anything under 8. Stat 2 units of blood rushed back to surgery within 24 hours. I was done with everything by 10pm Saturday night. Sunday urine output was normal, wasn't as tired and was eating regular diet. My PS came and said he was able to find the bleed as soon as I was opened and that's rare. My drains were putting out clearer drainage Saturday it was all dark red. My heart rate was still over 100 so he kept me an extra day and give 2 more units of blood. I was feeling fine but I was doing ok when I was bleeding so he wanted to be sure. Got home Monday night about 9pm. I cried a little not about missing breast just putting my girls through so much lately. They keep telling me it ok they are happy to take care of me and to stop worrying about them. I can take off my ace wrap at anytime but I like the compression feeling. On pain meds and antibiotics. Have appt with PS and Bs Friday. I'm taking care of myself emptying my 4 drains alone with my girls on stand by. Not allowed to shower yet and sleep in my bed. My Kids help me get comfortable adding and removing pillows positioning me and bringing whatever I need because once in bed takes lots of energy getting up. Glad everyone is doing great. I'm feeling more energetic too. Oh my doctor told me my path came back excellent no cancer anywhere margins were clear. I'm so happy! Hope everyone continues to heal. Now we must continue our journeys :)
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 01:26PM mgdsmc wrote: I'm sorry I wasn't clear. The port is placed under the skin so easy to hide and not easily infected. I have a power port. The only people allowed to draw from it are the chemo nurses which they do before each treatment. I had bi weekly chemo but weekly blood draws so they had to use a vein for that at the lab. The picc line is usually placed in the upper arm and have ports outside the skin. It has a dressing that has to be changed weekly and is sterile. They get infected a lot because its outside the body, dressing comes off ect. Chemo is hard on the veins but some people take that chance. I just know I got tired of being stuck so much and since they could only use one arm same vein each time.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 09:12AM mgdsmc wrote: MYL I not sure if the doctor explained the entire treatment plan when it comes to cancer treatment. I don't think it's a good idea to start treatment in another country and finish when you get home. Here's why: No one can be diagnosed staged or treated correctly without surgery first because scans don't tell the entire picture. Many of us went into surgery thinking our tumors were smaller with no node involvement but changed after surgery. I went into surgery stage one with no node involvement to stage 3a with 6/10 nodes positive plus 3 tumors. Plus unless you already have a MO you will have to wait for a referral to one. No doctor will treat you from test or scans from another country. You will have to start from scratch with test and scans again. So it doesn't make since to start treatment that you can't continue and the chemo meds could change. I had lumpectomy but my margins were clear. They wanted to go back in to clear them but I chose to do chemo first. I had grade 3 which chemo works best on. I had double MX and a complete response to chemo when they exam my breast in pathology. I know it's scary to walk around knowing you have BC but don't put yourself through extra stress by starting treatment that you can't finish. Good luck to youðŸ˜Š
